archetype_tagline: Pull yourself up by your bootstraps

demographics.education: Bachelor's in Business Administration, University of Texas Arlington
demographics.occupation: Regional Sales Manager, industrial equipment company (28 years)

life_experiences: Watched his father refuse to sue after a workplace accident: "Dad said a man handles his own problems
His sister filed for bankruptcy after credit card debt; Gary sees this as "poor choices
Successfully fought off a frivolous warranty claim at work, reinforcing belief that people try to game the system
His son struggled with addiction; Gary believes it was "choices, not disease
Pays high insurance premiums; resents "lawsuit culture" raising costs
Served on one prior jury (criminal DUI case, voted guilty)
No personal lawsuits filed or received
General belief that "good people don't end up in court

Direct, declarative statements

Dismissive of "excuses

question_1.question: "When someone is injured, what's usually the main cause?"
question_1.response: Nine times out of ten, it's something they did or didn't do. People don't pay attention anymore—they're on their phones, they're not watching where they're going. I'm not saying accidents don't happen, but usually there's something the person could have done differently.

question_2.question: "What's your reaction when you hear someone filed a personal injury lawsuit?"
question_2.response: Honestly? My first thought is 'here we go again.' I'm not saying every lawsuit is bogus, but it seems like everyone's looking for a payday these days. Whatever happened to just dealing with things?

question_3.question: "Have you or anyone close to you ever been seriously injured?"
question_3.response: My dad hurt his back pretty bad at work—herniated disc. He never sued, never complained. Just did his physical therapy and went back to work. That's how I was raised.

question_4.question: "Could you award money for pain and suffering?"
question_4.response: I mean, if I had to... but I'd need to see some real proof. Pain is subjective. How do you put a number on that? Seems like that's where these crazy awards come from.

question_5.question: "On a scale of 1-10, how difficult would it be to find a corporation liable?"
question_5.response: I'd say maybe a 4 or 5. I can do it if the evidence is there. But corporations aren't automatically bad guys just because they're big. They create jobs, they follow regulations. I've worked for companies my whole life.

question_6.question: "Do you think lawsuit awards are generally too high, too low, or about right?"
question_6.response: Too high, definitely. You hear about these multi-million dollar verdicts and it makes no sense. That's why everything costs so much—someone's gotta pay for all these lawsuits, and it's people like me.

deliberation_behavior.predicted_role: Will emerge as a vocal participant, possibly foreperson candidate
deliberation_behavior.deliberation_style: Verdict-driven; will want early vote, frame discussion around "what plaintiff did wrong"
likely_statements: Let's not get carried away with sympathy here
My taxes pay for these courts—let's not waste time
deliberation_behavior.persuadability: Low (0.25). Will dig in if challenged. Responds only to overwhelming factual evidence of defendant wrongdoing.
deliberation_behavior.faction_behavior: Will actively recruit followers, especially compliant/deferential jurors. May clash with Systemic Thinkers.

life_experiences: First husband was "lazy," blamed everyone else for his problems; divorce solidified her belief in personal responsibility
Worked her way up from receptionist to office manager without a degree
Her dental practice was sued once (she saw it as unfair, patient didn't follow post-op instructions)
Brother-in-law is on disability; she suspects he could work if he wanted to
Her own mother worked through pain until retirement; "that's just what you do
characteristic_phrases: I pulled myself up, why can't they?
Excuses are like... well, everyone's got one
I'm not unsympathetic, BUT...
What did they expect?
There's always more to the story
I've had hard times too, and I didn't sue anyone
More likely to acknowledge sympathy before dismissing
References her own struggles as benchmark
Less ideological than Gary, more experiential
Can be moved by genuine suffering but skeptical of motives

question_1.question: "When someone is injured, what's usually the main cause?"
question_1.response: It really depends. Sometimes it's just bad luck, but a lot of times people aren't being careful. I work in a dental office—you wouldn't believe how many patients don't follow instructions and then complain when things go wrong.

question_2.question: "Could you be fair to a plaintiff seeking damages for pain and suffering?"
question_2.response: I'd try. I know pain is real. But I also know some people exaggerate. I'd want to see medical records, hear from doctors. Not just take someone's word for it.

question_3.question: "Have you ever thought about suing someone but decided not to?"
question_3.response: Ha! After my divorce, I could have gone after my ex for all sorts of things. But I figured it wasn't worth the hassle. Sometimes you just have to move on.

deliberation_behavior.predicted_role: Active participant, not a leader but won't be silent
deliberation_behavior.deliberation_style: Will listen to evidence-focused arguments, can be persuaded if facts are strong

Watched peers who "made excuses" fall behind while he succeeded
Has experienced some discrimination but frames it as "obstacles to overcome, not excuses
Serves on his company's diversity committee; believes in "earning your seat
Dislikes both victim narratives AND systemic excuse-making
Holds Personal Responsibility views but with nuance about systemic barriers

question_1.question: "On a scale of 1-10, how difficult would it be to award a large sum for pain and suffering?"
question_1.response: Maybe a 6 or 7. I'm an analyst by trade—I like things I can measure. Pain and suffering is inherently subjective. I'd need a clear methodology for how the number was calculated, not just an emotional appeal.

question_2.question: "What's your view on personal responsibility?"
question_2.response: I believe in it strongly. That said, I also believe in accountability on all sides. If a company is negligent, they should be held accountable too. But I'd need to see clear evidence of that negligence, not assumptions.

question_3.question: "Can you be fair to both sides?"
question_3.response: Absolutely. I make decisions based on evidence every day in my job. I can set aside any preconceptions and evaluate what's presented in this courtroom. That's what I'd expect of myself.

deliberation_behavior.deliberation_style: Evidence-driven; will push for systematic evidence review before voting
influence_tactics: Logical analysis, "let's walk through the facts
May challenge emotional arguments from either direction
Will command respect due to professional demeanor
deliberation_behavior.persuadability: Moderate (0.45) but only through evidence-based arguments

demographics.education: High school diploma, some secretarial training

life_experiences: Parents immigrated from Sicily, built life through hard work, never complained
Raised four children on modest income; all are "productive citizens
Husband's death was "God's plan"; she coped through faith, not litigation
Believes suffering has meaning and builds character
Views lawsuit culture as symptom of moral decay

question_1.question: "Have you or anyone close to you experienced a serious injury or illness?"
question_1.response: My husband died of cancer at 54. He was a firefighter at Ground Zero. We never sued anyone. That's not how we were raised. You accept what God gives you and you go on.

question_2.question: "Would you be able to award compensation to someone for their injuries?"
question_2.response: If they really were injured by someone else's fault, yes. But I'd have to see proof. And I don't believe in these giant awards. What happened to being grateful for what you have?

question_3.question: "Do you believe the legal system treats people fairly?"
question_3.response: Mostly, yes. I think the problem is people abuse it. Too many lawsuits over nothing. It clogs up the courts when there are real criminals out there.

deliberation_behavior.predicted_role: Follower initially, but entrenched position makes her potential holdout
deliberation_behavior.persuadability: Very Low (0.15). Religious/moral framework is unshakeable.

question_1.question: "How do you feel about putting a dollar amount on pain and suffering?"
question_1.response: Honestly, it's difficult from my perspective. In my work, I quantify uncertainty all the time, but there's usually some objective basis. Pain is subjective. I'd need to see a methodology for how the number was derived, not just 'this feels right.'

question_2.question: "Could you award money for things that can't be precisely measured?"
question_2.response: I could, but I'd want some framework. Life expectancy tables, quality of life research, something to anchor the number. I'd be skeptical of arbitrary figures.

question_3.question: "How would you evaluate expert testimony?"
question_3.response: Very carefully. I'd look at their methodology, their assumptions, whether their analysis would hold up to peer review. Credentials aren't enough—I'd want to understand how they reached their conclusions.

deliberation_behavior.predicted_role: Evidence analyst; will scrutinize expert testimony carefully
deliberation_behavior.deliberation_style: Demands rigor; may slow down deliberation with methodological questions

life_experiences: Career auditing corporations; generally positive view of clients
Has seen fraudulent insurance claims and inflated damages
Represents business owners who complain about lawsuits
Approaches everything through financial lens
Believes in quantification and documentation
characteristic_phrases: Let's look at the actual financial impact

question_1.question: "Does your accounting background affect how you view damage claims?"
question_1.response: Probably. I'm trained to verify financial claims and look for supporting documentation. I'd want to see evidence for any damages claimed - medical bills, lost wages documentation, that kind of thing. I'm naturally skeptical of round numbers without backup.

characteristic_phrases: The law isn't always just

personas.tagline: I came here with $50 and built a business. What's your excuse?

personas.tagline: We don't sue our neighbors. We help them fix the fence.

personas.tagline: I worked 30 years with a bad back. Still never missed a day.
Doctors save lives. Sometimes patients don't listen.
I've tried cases for 25 years. I know how this works.
I've fought for workers my whole life. I'm not stopping now.
